channel.title: TEDTalks (video)
channel.description: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and partner events around the world. This podcast is also available in high-def video and audio-only formats.

channel.itunes:summary: TED is a nonprofit devoted to Ideas Worth Spreading. On this feed, you'll find TEDTalks video to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination from some of the world's leading thinkers and doers, speaking from the stage at TED conferences, TEDx events and partner events around the world. channel.itunes:keywords: TED, TEDTalks, TED Talks, inspiration, creativity, tech demo, education
channel.media:keywords: TED, TEDTalks, TED Talks, inspiration, creativity, tech demo, education
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: Each year, TED hosts 80 of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage. Each week, we'll release a new talk to inspire, intrigue and stir the imagination. For best effect, plan to listen to at least three, start to finish. (They have a cumulative effect.) If you have a curious soul and an open mind, we think you'll be hooked...

item.title: TED: Béatrice Coron: Stories cut from paper - Béatrice Coron (2011)
item.itunes:author: Béatrice Coron
item.description: With scissors and paper, artist Béatrice Coron creates intricate worlds, cities and countries, heavens and hells. Striding onstage in a glorious cape cut from Tyvek, she describes her creative process and the way her stories develop from snips and slices.
item.itunes:subtitle: Béatrice Coron: Stories cut from paper
item.itunes:summary: With scissors and paper, artist Béatrice Coron creates intricate worlds, cities and countries, heavens and hells. Striding onstage in a glorious cape cut from Tyvek, she describes her creative process and the way her stories develop from snips and slices.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research - Jay Bradner (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jay Bradner
item.description: How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1 -- and instead of patenting JQ1, they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jay Bradner: Open-source cancer research
item.itunes:summary: How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1 -- and instead of patenting JQ1, they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Malcolm Gladwell: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight - Malcolm Gladwell (2011)
item.itunes:author: Malcolm Gladwell
item.description: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result.
item.itunes:subtitle: Malcolm Gladwell: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight
item.itunes:summary: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Richard Wilkinson: How economic inequality harms societies - Richard Wilkinson (2011)
item.itunes:author: Richard Wilkinson
item.description: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Wilkinson: How economic inequality harms societies
item.itunes:summary: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms - Nathalie Miebach (2011)
item.itunes:author: Nathalie Miebach
item.description: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nathalie Miebach: Art made of storms
item.itunes:summary: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Todd Kuiken: A prosthetic arm that "feels" - Todd Kuiken (2011)
item.itunes:author: Todd Kuiken
item.description: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm.
item.itunes:subtitle: Todd Kuiken: A prosthetic arm that "feels"
item.itunes:summary: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Guy-Philippe Goldstein: How cyberattacks threaten real-world peace - Guy-Philippe Goldstein (2010)
item.itunes:author: Guy-Philippe Goldstein
item.description: More and more, nations are waging attacks with cyber weapons -- silent strikes on another country's computer systems that leave behind no trace. (Think of the Stuxnet worm.) At TEDxParis, Guy-Philippe Goldstein shows how cyberattacks can leap between the digital and physical worlds to prompt armed conflict -- and how we might avert this global security hazard.
item.itunes:subtitle: Guy-Philippe Goldstein: How cyberattacks threaten real-world peace
item.itunes:summary: More and more, nations are waging attacks with cyber weapons -- silent strikes on another country's computer systems that leave behind no trace. (Think of the Stuxnet worm.) At TEDxParis, Guy-Philippe Goldstein shows how cyberattacks can leap between the digital and physical worlds to prompt armed conflict -- and how we might avert this global security hazard.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Justin Hall-Tipping: Freeing energy from the grid - Justin Hall-Tipping (2011)
item.itunes:author: Justin Hall-Tipping
item.description: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs.
item.itunes:subtitle: Justin Hall-Tipping: Freeing energy from the grid
item.itunes:summary: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Bunker Roy: Learning from a barefoot movement - Bunker Roy (2011)
item.itunes:author: Bunker Roy
item.description: In Rajasthan, India, an extraordinary school teaches rural women and men -- many of them illiterate -- to become solar engineers, artisans, dentists and doctors in their own villages. It's called the Barefoot College, and its founder, Bunker Roy, explains how it works.
item.itunes:subtitle: Bunker Roy: Learning from a barefoot movement
item.itunes:summary: In Rajasthan, India, an extraordinary school teaches rural women and men -- many of them illiterate -- to become solar engineers, artisans, dentists and doctors in their own villages. It's called the Barefoot College, and its founder, Bunker Roy, explains how it works.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jae Rhim Lee: My mushroom burial suit - Jae Rhim Lee (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jae Rhim Lee
item.description: Here's a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally -- using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you'll ever see ...
item.itunes:subtitle: Jae Rhim Lee: My mushroom burial suit

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Pamela Meyer: How to spot a liar - Pamela Meyer (2011)
item.itunes:author: Pamela Meyer
item.description: On any given day we're lied to from 10 to 200 times, and the clues to detect those lie can be subtle and counter-intuitive. Pamela Meyer, author of Liespotting, shows the manners and "hotspots" used by those trained to recognize deception -- and she argues honesty is a value worth preserving.
item.itunes:subtitle: Pamela Meyer: How to spot a liar

Pamela Meyer, author of Liespotting, shows the manners and "hotspots" used by those trained to recognize deception -- and she argues honesty is a value worth preserving.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee - Ian Ritchie (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ian Ritchie
item.description: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Ritchie: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
item.itunes:summary: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Richard Seymour: How beauty feels - Richard Seymour (2011)
item.itunes:author: Richard Seymour
item.description: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful? And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Seymour: How beauty feels
item.itunes:summary: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful? And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Alison Gopnik: What do babies think? - Alison Gopnik (2011)
item.itunes:author: Alison Gopnik
item.description: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alison Gopnik: What do babies think?
item.itunes:summary: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Charles Hazlewood: Trusting the ensemble - Charles Hazlewood (2011)
item.itunes:author: Charles Hazlewood
item.description: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Hazlewood: Trusting the ensemble
item.itunes:summary: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Mike Biddle: We can recycle plastic - Mike Biddle (2011)
item.itunes:author: Mike Biddle
item.description: Less than 10% of plastic trash is recycled -- compared to almost 90% of metals -- because of the massively complicated problem of finding and sorting the different kinds. Frustrated by this waste, Mike Biddle has developed a cheap and incredibly energy efficient plant that can, and does, recycle any kind of plastic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike Biddle: We can recycle plastic

Frustrated by this waste, Mike Biddle has developed a cheap and incredibly energy efficient plant that can, and does, recycle any kind of plastic.

item.title: TED: Graham Hill: Less stuff, more happiness - Graham Hill (2011)
item.itunes:author: Graham Hill
item.description: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
item.itunes:subtitle: Graham Hill: Less stuff, more happiness
item.itunes:summary: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Christoph Adami: Finding life we can't imagine - Christoph Adami (2011)
item.itunes:author: Christoph Adami
item.description: How do we search for alien life if it's nothing like the life that we know? At TEDxUIUC Christoph Adami shows how he uses his research into artificial life -- self-replicating computer programs -- to find a signature, a 'biomarker,' that is free of our preconceptions of what life is.
item.itunes:subtitle: Christoph Adami: Finding life we can't imagine

item.title: TED: Yang Lan: The generation that's remaking China - Yang Lan (2011)
item.itunes:author: Yang Lan
item.description: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice.
item.itunes:subtitle: Yang Lan: The generation that's remaking China
item.itunes:summary: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice.

item.title: TED: Danielle de Niese: A flirtatious aria - Danielle de Niese (2011)
item.itunes:author: Danielle de Niese
item.description: Can opera be ever-so-slightly sexy? The glorious soprano Danielle de Niese shows how, singing the flirty "Meine Lippen, sie küssen so heiss." Which, translated, means, as you might guess: "I kiss so hot." From Giuditta by Frans Lehár; accompanist: Ingrid Surgenor.
item.itunes:subtitle: Danielle de Niese: A flirtatious aria

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Ben Goldacre: Battling bad science - Ben Goldacre (2011)
item.itunes:author: Ben Goldacre
item.description: Every day there are news reports of new health advice, but how can you know if they're right? Doctor and epidemiologist Ben Goldacre shows us, at high speed, the ways evidence can be distorted, from the blindingly obvious nutrition claims to the very subtle tricks of the pharmaceutical industry.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben Goldacre: Battling bad science

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jarreth Merz: Filming democracy in Ghana - Jarreth Merz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jarreth Merz
item.description: Jarreth Merz, a Swiss-Ghanaian filmmaker, came to Ghana in 2008 to film the national elections. What he saw there taught him new lessons about democracy -- and about himself.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jarreth Merz: Filming democracy in Ghana
item.itunes:summary: Jarreth Merz, a Swiss-Ghanaian filmmaker, came to Ghana in 2008 to film the national elections. What he saw there taught him new lessons about democracy -- and about himself.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Geoff Mulgan: A short intro to the Studio School - Geoff Mulgan (2011)
item.itunes:author: Geoff Mulgan
item.description: Some kids learn by listening; others learn by doing. Geoff Mulgan gives a short introduction to the Studio School, a new kind of school in the UK where small teams of kids learn by working on projects that are, as Mulgan puts it, "for real."
item.itunes:subtitle: Geoff Mulgan: A short intro to the Studio School

item.title: TED: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch - Abraham Verghese (2011)
item.itunes:author: Abraham Verghese
item.description: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
item.itunes:subtitle: Abraham Verghese: A doctor's touch
item.itunes:summary: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Sunni Brown: Doodlers, unite! - Sunni Brown (2011)
item.itunes:author: Sunni Brown
item.description: Studies show that sketching and doodling improve our comprehension -- and our creative thinking. So why do we still feel embarrassed when we're caught doodling in a meeting? Sunni Brown says: Doodlers, unite! She makes the case for unlocking your brain via pad and pen.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sunni Brown: Doodlers, unite!

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Elizabeth Murchison: Fighting a contagious cancer - Elizabeth Murchison (2011)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Murchison
item.description: What is killing the Tasmanian devil? A virulent cancer is infecting them by the thousands -- and unlike most cancers, it's contagious. Researcher Elizabeth Murchison tells us how she's fighting to save the Taz, and what she's learning about all cancers from this unusual strain. Contains disturbing images of facial cancer.
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Murchison: Fighting a contagious cancer

item.title: TED: Amy Lockwood: Selling condoms in the Congo - Amy Lockwood (2011)
item.itunes:author: Amy Lockwood
item.description: HIV is a serious problem in the DR Congo, and aid agencies have flooded the country with free and cheap condoms. But few people are using them. Why? "Reformed marketer" Amy Lockwood offers a surprising answer that upends a traditional model of philanthropy. (Some NSFW images.)
item.itunes:subtitle: Amy Lockwood: Selling condoms in the Congo

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: What we learned from 5 million books - Jean-Baptiste Michel / Erez Lieberman Aiden (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jean-Baptiste Michel / Erez Lieberman Aiden
item.description: Have you played with Google Labs' Ngram Viewer? It's an addicting tool that lets you search for words and ideas in a database of 5 million books from across centuries. Erez Lieberman Aiden and Jean-Baptiste Michel show us how it works, and a few of the surprising things we can learn from 500 billion words.
item.itunes:subtitle: What we learned from 5 million books

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Niall Ferguson: The 6 killer apps of prosperity - Niall Ferguson (2011)
item.itunes:author: Niall Ferguson
item.description: Over the past few centuries, Western cultures have been very good at creating general prosperity for themselves. Historian Niall Ferguson asks: Why the West, and less so the rest? He suggests half a dozen big ideas from Western culture -- call them the 6 killer apps -- that promote wealth, stability and innovation. And in this new century, he says, these apps are all shareable.

item.title: TED: Lauren Zalaznick: The conscience of television - Lauren Zalaznick (2010)
item.itunes:author: Lauren Zalaznick
item.description: TV executive Lauren Zalaznick thinks deeply about pop television. Sharing results of a bold study that tracks attitudes against TV ratings over five decades, she makes a case that television reflects who we truly are -- in ways we might not have expected.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lauren Zalaznick: The conscience of television

item.title: TED: Richard Resnick: Welcome to the genomic revolution - Richard Resnick (2011)
item.itunes:author: Richard Resnick
item.description: In this accessible talk from TEDxBoston, Richard Resnick shows how cheap and fast genome sequencing is about to turn health care (and insurance, and politics) upside down.
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Resnick: Welcome to the genomic revolution
item.itunes:summary: In this accessible talk from TEDxBoston, Richard Resnick shows how cheap and fast genome sequencing is about to turn health care (and insurance, and politics) upside down.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Kate Hartman: The art of wearable communication - Kate Hartman (2011)
item.itunes:author: Kate Hartman
item.description: Artist Kate Hartman uses wearable electronics to explore how we communicate, with ourselves and with the world. In this quirky and thought-provoking talk, she shows the "Talk to Yourself Hat", the "Inflatable Heart", the "Glacier Embracing Suit", and other unexpected devices.

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Misha Glenny: Hire the hackers! - Misha Glenny (2011)
item.itunes:author: Misha Glenny
item.description: Despite multibillion-dollar investments in cybersecurity, one of its root problems has been largely ignored: who are the people who write malicious code? Underworld investigator Misha Glenny profiles several convicted coders from around the world and reaches a startling conclusion.

item.title: TED: Yasheng Huang: Does democracy stifle economic growth? - Yasheng Huang (2011)
item.itunes:author: Yasheng Huang
item.description: Economist Yasheng Huang compares China to India, and asks how China's authoritarian rule contributed to its astonishing economic growth -- leading to a big question: Is democracy actually holding India back? Huang's answer may surprise you.
item.itunes:subtitle: Yasheng Huang: Does democracy stifle economic growth?

item.title: TED: Raghava KK: Shake up your story - Raghava KK (2011)
item.itunes:author: Raghava KK
item.description: Artist Raghava KK demos his new children's book for iPad with a fun feature: when you shake it, the story -- and your perspective -- changes. In this charming short talk, he invites all of us to shake up our perspective a little bit.
item.itunes:subtitle: Raghava KK: Shake up your story

item.title: TED: Lee Cronin: Making matter come alive - Lee Cronin (2011)
item.itunes:author: Lee Cronin
item.description: Before life existed on Earth, there was just matter, inorganic dead "stuff." How improbable is it that life arose? And -- could it use a different type of chemistry? Using an elegant definition of life (anything that can evolve), chemist Lee Cronin is exploring this question by attempting to create a fully inorganic cell using a "Lego kit" of inorganic molecules -- no carbon -- that can assemble, replicate and compete.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lee Cronin: Making matter come alive

item.title: TED: Edward Tenner: Unintended consequences - Edward Tenner (2011)
item.itunes:author: Edward Tenner
item.description: Every new invention changes the world -- in ways both intentional and unexpected. Historian Edward Tenner tells stories that illustrate the under-appreciated gap between our ability to innovate and our ability to foresee the consequences.
item.itunes:subtitle: Edward Tenner: Unintended consequences

item.title: TED: Joan Halifax: Compassion and the true meaning of empathy - Joan Halifax (2010)
item.itunes:author: Joan Halifax
item.description: Buddhist roshi Joan Halifax works with people at the last stage of life (in hospice and on death row). She shares what she's learned about compassion in the face of death and dying, and a deep insight into the nature of empathy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Joan Halifax: Compassion and the true meaning of empathy

item.title: TED: Skylar Tibbits: Can we make things that make themselves? - Skylar Tibbits (2011)
item.itunes:author: Skylar Tibbits
item.description: MIT researcher Skylar Tibbits works on self-assembly -- the idea that instead of building something (a chair, a skyscraper), we can create materials that build themselves, much the way a strand of DNA zips itself together. It's a big concept at early stages; Tibbits shows us three in-the-lab projects that hint at what a self-assembling future might look like.

item.title: TED: Julia Bacha: Pay attention to nonviolence - Julia Bacha (2011)
item.itunes:author: Julia Bacha
item.description: In 2003, the Palestinian village of Budrus mounted a 10-month-long nonviolent protest to stop a barrier being built across their olive groves. Did you hear about it? Didn't think so. Brazilian filmmaker Julia Bacha asks why we only pay attention to violence in the Israel-Palestine conflict -- and not to the nonviolent leaders who may one day bring peace.

item.title: TED: Svante Pääbo: DNA clues to our inner neanderthal - Svante Pääbo (2011)
item.itunes:author: Svante Pääbo
item.description: Sharing the results of a massive, worldwide study, geneticist Svante Pääbo shows the DNA proof that early humans mated with Neanderthals after we moved out of Africa. (Yes, many of us have Neanderthal DNA.) He also shows how a tiny bone from a baby finger was enough to identify a whole new humanoid species.

item.title: TED: Dan Ariely: Beware conflicts of interest - Dan Ariely (2011)
item.itunes:author: Dan Ariely
item.description: In this short talk, psychologist Dan Ariely tells two personal stories that explore scientific conflict of interest: How the pursuit of knowledge and insight can be affected, consciously or not, by shortsighted personal goals. When we're thinking about the big questions, he reminds us, let's be aware of our all-too-human brains.

item.title: TED: Marco Tempest: The magic of truth and lies (and iPods) - Marco Tempest (2011)
item.itunes:author: Marco Tempest
item.description: Using three iPods like magical props, Marco Tempest spins a clever, surprisingly heartfelt meditation on truth and lies, art and emotion.

item.title: TED: Lucianne Walkowicz: Finding planets around other stars - Lucianne Walkowicz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Lucianne Walkowicz
item.description: How do we find planets -- even habitable planets -- around other stars? By looking for tiny dimming as a planet passes in front of its sun, TED Fellow Lucianne Walkowicz and the Kepler mission have found some 1,200 potential new planetary systems. With new techniques, they may even find ones with the right conditions for life.

item.title: TED: Jeremy Gilley: One day of peace - Jeremy Gilley (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jeremy Gilley
item.description: Here's a crazy idea: Persuade the world to try living in peace for just one day, every September 21. In this energetic, honest talk, Jeremy Gilley tells the story of how this crazy idea became real -- real enough to help millions of kids in war-torn regions.

item.description: Psychologist Philip Zimbardo asks, "Why are boys struggling?" He shares some stats (lower graduation rates, greater worries about intimacy and relationships) and suggests a few reasons -- and challenges the TED community to think about solutions.

item.itunes:author: Eve Ensler
item.description: Poet, writer, activist Eve Ensler lived in her head. In this powerful talk from TEDWomen, she talks about her lifelong disconnection from her body -- and how two shocking events helped her to connect with the reality, the physicality of being human.

item.title: TED: Jessica Green: Are we filtering the wrong microbes? - Jessica Green (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jessica Green
item.description: Should we keep the outdoors out of hospitals? Ecologist and TED Fellow Jessica Green has found that mechanical ventilation does get rid of many types of microbes, but the wrong kinds: the ones left in the hospital are much more likely to be pathogens.

item.title: TED: Mark Pagel: How language transformed humanity - Mark Pagel (2011)
item.itunes:author: Mark Pagel
item.description: Biologist Mark Pagel shares an intriguing theory about why humans evolved our complex system of language. He suggests that language is a piece of "social technology" that allowed early human tribes to access a powerful new tool: cooperation.

item.title: TED: Harald Haas: Wireless data from every light bulb - Harald Haas (2011)
item.itunes:author: Harald Haas
item.description: What if every light bulb in the world could also transmit data? At TEDGlobal, Harald Haas demonstrates, for the first time, a device that could do exactly that. By flickering the light from a single LED, a change too quick for the human eye to detect, he can transmit far more data than a cellular tower -- and do it in a way that's more efficient, secure and widespread.

item.itunes:author: Adam Ostrow
item.description: Many of us have a social media presence -- a virtual personality made up of status updates, tweets and connections, stored in the cloud. Adam Ostrow asks a big question: What happens to that personality after you've died? Could it ... live on?

item.title: TED: Julian Treasure: 5 ways to listen better - Julian Treasure (2011)
item.itunes:author: Julian Treasure
item.description: In our louder and louder world, says sound expert Julian Treasure, "We are losing our listening." In this short, fascinating talk, Treasure shares five ways to re-tune your ears for conscious listening -- to other people and the world around you.

item.title: TED: Josette Sheeran: Ending hunger now - Josette Sheeran (2011)
item.itunes:author: Josette Sheeran
item.description: Josette Sheeran, the head of the UN's World Food Program, talks about why, in a world with enough food for everyone, people still go hungry, still die of starvation, still use food as a weapon of war. Her vision: "Food is one issue that cannot be solved person by person. We have to stand together."

item.title: TED: Paul Bloom: The origins of pleasure - Paul Bloom (2011)
item.itunes:author: Paul Bloom
item.description: Why do we like an original painting better than a forgery? Psychologist Paul Bloom argues that human beings are essentialists -- that our beliefs about the history of an object change how we experience it, not simply as an illusion, but as a deep feature of what pleasure (and pain) is.

item.title: TED: Geoffrey West: The surprising math of cities and corporations - Geoffrey West (2011)
item.itunes:author: Geoffrey West
item.description: Physicist Geoffrey West has found that simple, mathematical laws govern the properties of cities -- that wealth, crime rate, walking speed and many other aspects of a city can be deduced from a single number: the city's population. In this mind-bending talk from TEDGlobal he shows how it works and how similar laws hold for organisms and corporations.

item.title: TED: Rory Stewart: Time to end the war in Afghanistan - Rory Stewart (2011)
item.itunes:author: Rory Stewart
item.description: British MP Rory Stewart walked across Afghanistan after 9/11, talking with citizens and warlords alike. Now, a decade later, he asks: Why are Western and coalition forces still fighting there? He shares lessons from past military interventions that worked -- Bosnia, for instance -- and shows that humility and local expertise are the keys to success.

item.title: TED: A robot that flies like a bird - Markus Fischer (2011)
item.itunes:author: Markus Fischer
item.description: Plenty of robots can fly -- but none can fly like a real bird. That is, until Markus Fischer and his team at Festo built SmartBird, a large, lightweight robot, modeled on a seagull, that flies by flapping its wings. A soaring demo fresh from TEDGlobal 2011.

item.title: TED: Kevin Slavin: How algorithms shape our world - Kevin Slavin (2011)
item.itunes:author: Kevin Slavin
item.description: Kevin Slavin argues that we're living in a world designed for -- and increasingly controlled by -- algorithms. In this riveting talk from TEDGlobal, he shows how these complex computer programs determine: espionage tactics, stock prices, movie scripts, and architecture. And he warns that we are writing code we can't understand, with implications we can't control.

item.itunes:author: Thandie Newton
item.description: Actor Thandie Newton tells the story of finding her "otherness" -- first, as a child growing up in two distinct cultures, and then as an actor playing with many different selves. A warm, wise talk, fresh from stage at TEDGlobal 2011.

item.itunes:author: Mikko Hypponen
item.description: It's been 25 years since the first PC virus (Brain A) hit the net, and what was once an annoyance has become a sophisticated tool for crime and espionage. Computer security expert Mikko Hyppönen tells us how we can stop these new viruses from threatening the internet as we know it.

item.itunes:author: Nadia Al-Sakkaf
item.description: As political turmoil in Yemen continues, the editor of the Yemen Times, Nadia Al-Sakkaf, talks at TEDGlobal with host Pat Mitchell. Al-Sakkaf's independent, English-language paper is vital for sharing news -- and for sharing a new vision of Yemen and of that country's women as equal partners in work and change.

item.itunes:author: Maajid Nawaz

A powerful talk from TEDGlobal 2011.

item.title: TED: Rebecca MacKinnon: Let's take back the Internet! - Rebecca MacKinnon (2011)
item.itunes:author: Rebecca MacKinnon
item.description: In this powerful talk from TEDGlobal, Rebecca MacKinnon describes the expanding struggle for freedom and control in cyberspace, and asks: How do we design the next phase of the Internet with accountability and freedom at its core, rather than control? She believes the internet is headed for a "Magna Carta" moment when citizens around the world demand that their governments protect free speech and their right to connection.

item.itunes:author: Nina Tandon
item.description: Tissue engineer and TED Fellow Nina Tandon is growing artificial hearts and bones. To do that, she needs new ways of caring for artificially grown cells -- techniques she's developed by the simple but powerful method of copying their natural environments.

item.itunes:author: Simon Lewis

item.title: TED: Jonathan Drori: The beautiful tricks of flowers - Jonathan Drori (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jonathan Drori
item.description: In this visually dazzling talk, Jonathan Drori shows the extraordinary ways flowering plants -- over a quarter million species -- have evolved to attract insects to spread their pollen: growing 'landing-strips' to guide the insects in, shining in ultraviolet, building elaborate traps, and even mimicking other insects in heat.

item.title: TED: Emiliano Salinas: A civil response to violence - Emiliano Salinas (2010)
item.itunes:author: Emiliano Salinas
item.description: In this passionate talk from TEDxSanMigueldeAllende that's already caused a sensation in Mexico, Emiliano Salinas, son of former president Carlos Salinas de Gortari, confronts the current climate of violence in Mexico -- or rather, how Mexican society responds to it. He calls on ordinary citizens to move from denial and fear to peaceful, community-based action. This is the first talk posted on TED.com that was delivered in a language other than English. (It has English subtitles by default.)

item.itunes:author: Joshua Walters
item.description: At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, comedian Joshua Walters, who's bipolar, walks the line between mental illness and mental "skillness." In this funny, thought-provoking talk, he asks: What's the right balance between medicating craziness away and riding the manic edge of creativity and drive?
item.itunes:subtitle: Joshua Walters: On being just crazy enough
item.itunes:summary: At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, comedian Joshua Walters, who's bipolar, walks the line between mental illness and mental "skillness." In this funny, thought-provoking talk, he asks: What's the right balance between medicating craziness away and riding the manic edge of creativity and drive?
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Honor Harger: A history of the universe in sound - Honor Harger (2011)
item.itunes:author: Honor Harger
item.description: Artist-technologist Honor Harger listens to the weird and wonderful noises of stars and planets and pulsars. In her work, she tracks the radio waves emitted by ancient celestial objects and turns them into sound, including "the oldest song you will ever hear," the sound of cosmic rays left over from the Big Bang.
item.itunes:subtitle: Honor Harger: A history of the universe in sound

In her work, she tracks the radio waves emitted by ancient celestial objects and turns them into sound, including "the oldest song you will ever hear," the sound of cosmic rays left over from the Big Bang.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jok Church: A circle of caring - Jok Church (2007)
item.itunes:author: Jok Church
item.description: In this 3-minute talk, cartoonist and educator Jok Church tells a moving story of the teacher who cared for him when no one else did -- and how he returned the favor.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jok Church: A circle of caring
item.itunes:summary: In this 3-minute talk, cartoonist and educator Jok Church tells a moving story of the teacher who cared for him when no one else did -- and how he returned the favor.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Daniel Tammet: Different ways of knowing - Daniel Tammet (2011)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Tammet
item.description: Daniel Tammet has linguistic, numerical and visual synesthesia -- meaning that his perception of words, numbers and colors are woven together into a new way of perceiving and understanding the world. The author of "Born on a Blue Day," Tammet shares his art and his passion for languages in this glimpse into his beautiful mind.
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Tammet: Different ways of knowing
item.itunes:summary: Daniel Tammet has linguistic, numerical and visual synesthesia -- meaning that his perception of words, numbers and colors are woven together into a new way of perceiving and understanding the world. The author of "Born on a Blue Day," Tammet shares his art and his passion for languages in this glimpse into his beautiful mind.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Bill Ford: A future beyond traffic gridlock - Bill Ford (2011)
item.itunes:author: Bill Ford
item.description: Bill Ford is a car guy -- his great-grandfather was Henry Ford, and he grew up inside the massive Ford Motor Co. So when he worries about cars' impact on the environment, and about our growing global gridlock problem, it's worth a listen. His vision for the future of mobility includes "smart roads," even smarter public transport and going green like never before.

item.title: TED: Maya Beiser(s) and her cello(s) - Maya Beiser (2011)
item.itunes:author: Maya Beiser
item.description: Cellist Maya Beiser plays a gorgeous eight-part modern etude with seven copies of herself, and segues into a meditative music/video hybrid -- using tech to create endless possibilities for transformative sound. Music is Steve Reich's "Cello Counterpoint," with video from Bill Morrison, then David Lang's "World to Come," with video by Irit Batsry.

item.title: TED: Onyx Ashanti: This is beatjazz - Onyx Ashanti (2011)
item.itunes:author: Onyx Ashanti
item.description: Musician and inventor Onyx Ashanti demonstrates "beatjazz" -- his music created with two handheld controllers, an iPhone and a mouthpiece, and played with the entire body. At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, after locking in his beats and loops, he plays a 3-minute song that shares his vision for the future of music.

item.title: TED: Camille Seaman: Haunting photos of polar ice - Camille Seaman (2011)
item.itunes:author: Camille Seaman
item.description: Photographer Camille Seaman shoots icebergs, showing the world the complex beauty of these massive, ancient chunks of ice. Dive in to her photo slideshow, "The Last Iceberg."
item.itunes:subtitle: Camille Seaman: Haunting photos of polar ice

item.title: TED: Steve Keil: A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond - Steve Keil (2011)
item.itunes:author: Steve Keil
item.description: At TEDxBG in Sofia, Steve Keil fights the "serious meme" that has infected his home of Bulgaria -- and calls for a return to play to revitalize the economy, education and society. A sparkling talk with a universal message for people everywhere who are reinventing their workplaces, schools, lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Steve Keil: A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond

item.title: TED: Shea Hembrey: How I became 100 artists - Shea Hembrey (2011)
item.itunes:author: Shea Hembrey
item.description: How do you stage an international art show with work from 100 different artists? If you're Shea Hembrey, you invent all of the artists and artwork yourself -- from large-scale outdoor installations to tiny paintings drawn with a single-haired brush. Watch this funny, mind-bending talk to see the explosion of creativity and diversity of skills a single artist is capable of.

item.title: TED: Daniel Kraft: Medicine's future? There's an app for that - Daniel Kraft (2011)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Kraft
item.description: At TEDxMaastricht, Daniel Kraft offers a fast-paced look at the next few years of innovations in medicine, powered by new tools, tests and apps that bring diagnostic information right to the patient's bedside.
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Kraft: Medicine's future? There's an app for that

item.title: TED: JD Schramm: Break the silence for suicide survivors - JD Schramm (2011)
item.itunes:author: JD Schramm
item.description: Even when our lives appear fine from the outside, locked within can be a world of quiet suffering, leading some to the decision to end their life. At TEDYou, JD Schramm asks us to break the silence surrounding suicide and suicide attempts, and to create much-needed resources to help people who reclaim their life after escaping death. Resources: http://t.co/wsNrY9C

item.title: TED: Alice Dreger: Is anatomy destiny? - Alice Dreger (2010)
item.itunes:author: Alice Dreger
item.description: Alice Dreger works with people at the edge of anatomy, such as conjoined twins and intersexed people. In her observation, it's often a fuzzy line between male and female, among other anatomical distinctions. Which brings up a huge question: Why do we let our anatomy determine our fate?

item.title: TED: Paul Romer: The world's first charter city? - Paul Romer (2011)
item.itunes:author: Paul Romer
item.description: Back in 2009, Paul Romer unveiled the idea for a "charter city" -- a new kind of city with rules that favor democracy and trade. This year, at TED2011, he tells the story of how such a city might just happen in Honduras ... with a little help from his TEDTalk.
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Romer: The world's first charter city?

item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Janet Echelman: Taking imagination seriously - Janet Echelman (2011)
item.itunes:author: Janet Echelman
item.description: Janet Echelman found her true voice as an artist when her paints went missing -- which forced her to look to an unorthodox new art material. Now she makes billowing, flowing, building-sized sculpture with a surprisingly geeky edge. A transporting 10 minutes of pure creativity.
item.itunes:subtitle: Janet Echelman: Taking imagination seriously
item.itunes:summary: Janet Echelman found her true voice as an artist when her paints went missing -- which forced her to look to an unorthodox new art material. Now she makes billowing, flowing, building-sized sculpture with a surprisingly geeky edge. A transporting 10 minutes of pure creativity.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Jack Horner: Building a dinosaur from a chicken - Jack Horner (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jack Horner
item.description: Renowned paleontologist Jack Horner has spent his career trying to reconstruct a dinosaur. He's found fossils with extraordinarily well-preserved blood vessels and soft tissues, but never intact DNA. So, in a new approach, he's taking living descendants of the dinosaur (chickens) and genetically engineering them to reactivate ancestral traits — including teeth, tails, and even hands — to make a "Chickenosaurus".
item.itunes:subtitle: Jack Horner: Building a dinosaur from a chicken

item.title: TED: Damon Horowitz calls for a "moral operating system" - Damon Horowitz (2011)
item.itunes:author: Damon Horowitz
item.description: At TEDxSiliconValley, Damon Horowitz reviews the enormous new powers that technology gives us: to know more -- and more about each other -- than ever before. Drawing the audience into a philosophical discussion, Horowitz invites us to pay new attention to the basic philosophy -- the ethical principles -- behind the burst of invention remaking our world. Where's the moral operating system that allows us to make sense of it?
item.itunes:subtitle: Damon Horowitz calls for a "moral operating system"

item.title: TED: Jessi Arrington: Wearing nothing new - Jessi Arrington (2011)
item.itunes:author: Jessi Arrington
item.description: Designer Jessi Arrington packed nothing for TED but 7 pairs of undies, buying the rest of her clothes in thrift stores around LA. It's a meditation on conscious consumption -- wrapped in a rainbow of color and creativity.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jessi Arrington: Wearing nothing new

item.title: TED: Aaron O'Connell: Making sense of a visible quantum object - Aaron O'Connell (2011)
item.itunes:author: Aaron O'Connell
item.description: Physicists are used to the idea that subatomic particles behave according to the bizarre rules of quantum mechanics, completely different to human-scale objects. In a breakthrough experiment, Aaron O'Connell has blurred that distinction by creating an object that is visible to the unaided eye, but provably in two places at the same time. In this talk he suggests an intriguing way of thinking about the result.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aaron O'Connell: Making sense of a visible quantum object

item.title: TED: Stefan Sagmeister: 7 rules for making more happiness - Stefan Sagmeister (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stefan Sagmeister
item.description: Using simple, delightful illustrations, designer Stefan Sagmeister shares his latest thinking on happiness -- both the conscious and unconscious kind. His seven rules for life and design happiness can (with some customizations) apply to everyone seeking more joy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stefan Sagmeister: 7 rules for making more happiness

item.title: TED: Dennis Hong: Making a car for blind drivers - Dennis Hong (2011)
item.itunes:author: Dennis Hong
item.description: Using robotics, laser rangefinders, GPS and smart feedback tools, Dennis Hong is building a car for drivers who are blind. It's not a "self-driving" car, he's careful to note, but a car in which a non-sighted driver can determine speed, proximity and route -- and drive independently.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dennis Hong: Making a car for blind drivers

It's not a "self-driving" car, he's careful to note, but a car in which a non-sighted driver can determine speed, proximity and route -- and drive independently.
item.dc:creator: TEDTalks

item.title: TED: Robert Gupta and Joshua Roman duet on "Passacaglia" - Robert Gupta / Joshua Roman (2011)
item.itunes:author: Robert Gupta / Joshua Roman
item.description: It's a master class in collaboration as violinist Robert Gupta and cellist Joshua Roman perform Halvorsen's "Passacaglia" for violin and viola. Roman takes the viola part on his Stradivarius cello. It's powerful to watch the two musicians connect moment to moment (and recover from a mid-performance hiccup). The two are both TED Fellows, and their deep connection powers this sparkling duet.
item.itunes:subtitle: Robert Gupta and Joshua Roman duet on "Passacaglia"

item.title: TED: Mustafa Akyol: Faith versus tradition in Islam - Mustafa Akyol (2011)
item.itunes:author: Mustafa Akyol
item.description: At TEDxWarwick, journalist Mustafa Akyol talks about the way that some local cultural practices (such as wearing a headscarf) have become linked, in the popular mind, to the articles of faith of Islam. Has the world's general idea of the Islamic faith focused too much on tradition, and not enough on core beliefs?

item.title: TED: Shirin Neshat: Art in exile - Shirin Neshat (2010)
item.itunes:author: Shirin Neshat
item.description: Iranian-born artist Shirin Neshat explores the paradox of being an artist in exile: a voice for her people, but unable to go home. In her work, she explores Iran pre- and post-Islamic Revolution, tracing political and societal change through powerful images of women.
item.itunes:subtitle: Shirin Neshat: Art in exile

item.title: TED: Bruce Aylward: How we'll stop polio for good - Bruce Aylward (2011)
item.itunes:author: Bruce Aylward
item.description: Polio is almost completely eradicated. But as Bruce Aylward says: Almost isn't good enough with a disease this terrifying. Aylward lays out the plan to continue the scientific miracle that ended polio in most of the world -- and to snuff it out everywhere, forever.
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce Aylward: How we'll stop polio for good

item.title: TED: Aaron Koblin: Artfully visualizing our humanity - Aaron Koblin (2011)
item.itunes:author: Aaron Koblin
item.description: Artist Aaron Koblin takes vast amounts of data -- and at times vast numbers of people -- and weaves them into stunning visualizations. From elegant lines tracing airline flights to landscapes of cell phone data, from a Johnny Cash video assembled from crowd-sourced drawings to the "Wilderness Downtown" video that customizes for the user, his works brilliantly explore how modern technology can make us more human.

item.title: TED: Sarah Kaminsky: My father the forger - Sarah Kaminsky (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sarah Kaminsky
item.description: Sarah Kaminsky tells the extraordinary story of her father Adolfo and his activity during World War II -- using his ingenuity and talent for forgery to save lives.
